docs.title: AMS & Humidity Monitoring
docs.text: Bambuddy provides comprehensive monitoring for your AMS (Automatic Material System) and AMS-HT (High Temperature) units.

docs.title: AMS Slot Status
docs.text:
Each AMS slot displays:

Information Description Filament color Visual color swatch Material type PLA, PETG, ABS, ASA, etc. Remaining Estimated filament left Active Currently feeding indicator

docs.title: Multi-AMS Support
docs.text:
Bambuddy supports multiple AMS units per printer:

  • Up to 4 AMS units (16 total slots)
  • Each unit displayed with its slots
  • Visual indication of active slot during printing

docs.title: Humidity Monitoring
docs.text: Track humidity levels inside your AMS units:

docs.title: Current Reading
docs.text:
The humidity percentage is displayed on the printer card:

Level Status Action < 20% Excellent None needed 20-40% Good None needed 40-60% Fair Consider drying > 60% High Replace desiccant

docs.title: Configurable Thresholds
docs.text:
Set custom warning thresholds in Settings:

  1. Go to Settings > General
  2. Find AMS Humidity Threshold
  3. Set your preferred warning level
  4. Save changes

Filament Sensitivity

Different filaments have different humidity sensitivities. PLA is more tolerant than Nylon or PETG.

docs.title: Temperature Monitoring
docs.text:
For AMS-HT (High Temperature) units, temperature is also tracked:

Reading Description Current temp Live temperature inside the unit Target temp Configured drying temperature Status Heating, holding, or idle

docs.title: Historical Charts
docs.text: Click on the humidity or temperature indicator to view historical data:

docs.title: Time Ranges
docs.text:
• 6 hours - Recent trends
  • 24 hours - Daily pattern
  • 48 hours - Extended view
  • 7 days - Weekly overview

docs.title: Chart Features
docs.text:
• Min/Max/Avg statistics
  • Threshold reference lines
  • Interactive tooltips
  • Zoom and pan

docs.title: Data Retention
docs.text: AMS data is stored for historical analysis:

docs.title: Default Retention
docs.text:
• 30 days of humidity/temperature data
  • Configurable in Settings

docs.title: Configuring Retention
docs.text:
1. Go to Settings > General
  2. Find AMS Data Retention
  3. Set number of days (1-365)
  4. Older data is automatically purged

Storage Impact

Longer retention periods increase database size. Consider your available storage.

docs.text:
Desiccant Maintenance

When humidity consistently stays high, it's time to replace or regenerate your desiccant packets.

docs.title: API Keys & Webhooks
docs.text: Integrate Bambuddy with external tools using API keys and webhooks.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
API keys allow external applications to:

  • Access Bambuddy data
  • Trigger actions
  • Integrate with automation tools

docs.title: Creating an API Key
docs.text:
1. Go to Settings > API Keys
  2. Click Create API Key
  3. Enter a name (e.g., "Home Assistant")
  4. Select permissions
  5. Click Create
  6. Copy the key immediately - it won't be shown again!

Save Your Key

API keys are shown only once at creation. Store it securely.

docs.title: Available Permissions
docs.text: Permission Allows Read Printers View printer status Control Printers Start/stop/pause prints Read Archives View archive data Write Archives Edit/delete archives Read Statistics View statistics Read Queue View print queue Write Queue Add/remove from queue Read Settings View configuration Write Settings Modify configuration Admin Full access

docs.title: Principle of Least Privilege
docs.text:
Only grant permissions that are needed:

  • Read-only for dashboards
  • Control for automation
  • Admin only when necessary

docs.title: Authentication
docs.text:
Include the API key in request headers:

curl -H "X-API-Key: your-api-key-here" \
  http://localhost:8000/api/v1/printers

docs.title: Base URL
docs.text: http://your-server:8000/api/v1

docs.title: Common Endpoints
docs.text:
Endpoint Method Description /printers GET List all printers /printers/{id} GET Get printer details /printers/{id}/status GET Get printer status /archives GET List archives /archives/{id} GET Get archive details /queue GET View print queue /queue POST Add to queue /statistics GET Get statistics

See API Reference for complete documentation.

docs.title: Outgoing Webhooks
docs.text:
Bambuddy can send notifications to external URLs:

  1. Go to Settings > Notifications
  2. Add a Webhook provider
  3. Enter your endpoint URL
  4. Configure events to trigger

docs.title: Payload Format
docs.text:
{
  "event": "print_complete",
  "timestamp": "2024-01-15T14:30:00Z",
  "data": {
    "printer": "Workshop X1C",
    "filename": "benchy.3mf",
    "duration": 8100,
    "filament_used": 45.2,
    "status": "success"
  }
}

docs.title: Events
docs.text: Event Trigger print_started Print begins print_progress Progress milestone print_complete Print finishes print_failed Print fails printer_offline Connection lost printer_error HMS error

docs.title: Home Assistant
docs.text:
Use REST sensors to display status:

sensor:
  - platform: rest
    name: "Bambuddy Printer Status"
    resource: "http://bambuddy:8000/api/v1/printers/1/status"
    headers:
      X-API-Key: "your-api-key"
    value_template: "{{ value_json.state }}"
    json_attributes:
      - progress
      - remaining_time
      - temperature

Trigger automations on webhook events.

docs.title: Node-RED
docs.text: Use HTTP request nodes with API key authentication.

docs.title: IFTTT / Zapier
docs.text: Use webhook triggers and actions.

docs.title: Viewing Keys
docs.text:
See all API keys in Settings:

  • Name
  • Created date
  • Last used
  • Permissions

docs.title: Revoking Keys
docs.text:
Delete keys that are no longer needed:

  1. Find the key in the list
  2. Click Delete
  3. Confirm deletion

Key is immediately invalidated.

docs.title: Rotating Keys
docs.text:
Best practice: Rotate keys periodically:

  1. Create new key
  2. Update applications
  3. Delete old key

docs.title: Key Storage
docs.text:
• Never commit keys to version control
  • Use environment variables
  • Store in secrets managers

docs.title: Network Security
docs.text:
• Use HTTPS for external access
  • Limit API access to trusted IPs if possible
  • Consider VPN for remote access

docs.title: Monitoring
docs.text:
• Review API key usage
  • Check for unauthorized access
  • Revoke unused keys

docs.title: Permissions
docs.text:
• Use minimum required permissions
  • Create separate keys per application
  • Avoid using admin keys in automation

docs.title: Current Limits
docs.text: Endpoint Type Limit Read 100/minute Write 30/minute Control 10/minute

docs.title: Rate Limit Headers
docs.text:
Responses include rate limit info:

X-RateLimit-Limit: 100
X-RateLimit-Remaining: 95
X-RateLimit-Reset: 1705331400

docs.title: 401 Unauthorized
docs.text:
• Check API key is correct
  • Verify key hasn't been revoked
  • Ensure header name is X-API-Key

docs.title: 403 Forbidden
docs.text:
• Check key has required permissions
  • Verify endpoint matches permissions

docs.title: 429 Too Many Requests
docs.text:
• Rate limit exceeded
  • Wait and retry
  • Check for runaway automation

docs.title: Tips
docs.text:
Descriptive Names

Name keys after their purpose: "Home Assistant Dashboard" not "key1".

Separate Keys

Use different keys for different applications for easy management.

Regular Audit

Review API keys periodically and remove unused ones.

Test First

Test API calls manually before implementing in automation.

Document Usage

Keep notes on which keys are used where.

docs.title: Print Archiving
docs.text: Bambuddy automatically archives every completed print with full metadata, 3D previews, and duplicate detection.

docs.title: How Archiving Works
docs.text:
When a print completes:

graph LR
    A[Print Completes] --> B[Download 3MF]
    B --> C[Extract Metadata]
    C --> D[Generate Thumbnail]
    D --> E[Check Duplicates]
    E --> F[Save to Archive]

docs.title: What Gets Archived
docs.text: Data Description 3MF File Complete print file from printer Thumbnail Preview image from slicer Metadata Print settings, layers, filament, etc. Print result Success, failed, or stopped Duration Actual print time Filament used Grams consumed Camera snapshot Photo at completion (if enabled)

docs.title: Duplicate Detection
docs.text: Bambuddy automatically detects duplicate prints:

docs.text:

docs.title: Managing Duplicates
docs.text:

docs.title: Backup & Restore
docs.text: Protect your print history with database backups and restore when needed.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Bambuddy's backup system:

  • Full database backup - All your data
  • Selective restore - Choose what to restore
  • User settings included - Preferences preserved
  • Archives included - Print history saved

docs.title: Manual Backup
docs.text:
1. Go to Settings > Backup
  2. Click Create Backup
  3. Wait for backup to complete
  4. Download the backup file

docs.title: Backup Contents
docs.text: Data Included Print archives Printer configs User settings Notification configs Smart plug configs K-profiles External links Projects Maintenance records API keys

docs.title: What's NOT Included
docs.text: Data Reason 3MF files Too large (download separately) Thumbnails Regenerated from archives Logs Not needed for restore Cache Temporary data

docs.title: Format
docs.text:
Backup files are SQLite database exports:

bambuddy_backup_2024-01-15_143022.db

docs.title: File Size
docs.text:
Typical sizes:

  • 100 prints: ~5-10 MB
  • 1,000 prints: ~50-100 MB
  • 10,000 prints: ~500 MB - 1 GB

Size depends on metadata stored per print.

docs.title: Full Restore
docs.text:
Restore everything from a backup:

  1. Go to Settings > Backup
  2. Click Restore from Backup
  3. Select your backup file
  4. Click Full Restore
  5. Confirm (this overwrites current data)
  6. Wait for restore to complete
  7. Restart Bambuddy

Full Restore Overwrites

A full restore replaces all current data. Create a backup first!

docs.title: Selective Restore
docs.text:
Choose specific data to restore:

  1. Click Restore from Backup
  2. Select backup file
  3. Choose Selective Restore
  4. Check items to restore:
  5. Archives
  6. Printers
  7. Settings
  8. Notifications
  9. Projects
  10. Click Restore Selected

docs.title: Merge vs Replace
docs.text: Mode Behavior Replace Overwrites existing data Merge Adds to existing (may duplicate)

docs.title: Automatic Backups
docs.text:
Configure automatic backups:

  1. Go to Settings > Backup
  2. Enable Automatic Backups
  3. Set schedule:
  4. Daily
  5. Weekly
  6. Monthly
  7. Set retention (how many to keep)
  8. Optionally set backup location

docs.title: Backup Retention
docs.text:
Automatic cleanup of old backups:

Setting Effect Keep 5 Deletes 6th oldest Keep 10 Deletes 11th oldest Keep all No deletion

docs.title: Location
docs.text:
The database is stored at:

/path/to/bambuddy/bambuddy.db

docs.title: Direct Backup
docs.text:
Copy the database file directly:

cp bambuddy.db bambuddy_backup_$(date +%Y%m%d).db

Stop Bambuddy First

Stop Bambuddy before copying to ensure consistency.

docs.title: SQLite Tools
docs.text:
Use SQLite tools for advanced operations:

# Dump to SQL
sqlite3 bambuddy.db .dump > backup.sql

# Restore from SQL
sqlite3 new.db < backup.sql

docs.title: Downloading Archives
docs.text: 3MF files aren't in database backups. Download separately:

docs.title: Individual Download
docs.text:
1. Open an archive
  2. Click Download 3MF

docs.title: Bulk Export
docs.text:
1. Go to Archives
  2. Click Export
  3. Select Include 3MF files
  4. Download the archive

docs.title: Lost Database
docs.text:
If database is corrupted or deleted:

  1. Stop Bambuddy
  2. Remove corrupted bambuddy.db
  3. Start Bambuddy (creates fresh database)
  4. Go to Settings > Backup
  5. Restore from your backup

docs.title: New Installation
docs.text:
Moving to a new server:

  1. Install Bambuddy on new server
  2. Copy backup file to new server
  3. Go to Settings > Backup
  4. Full restore from backup

docs.title: Data Migration
docs.text:
Moving between versions:

  1. Create backup on old version
  2. Upgrade Bambuddy
  3. If needed, restore from backup

docs.title: Backup Schedule
docs.text: Frequency Good For Daily Active printing Weekly Regular use Monthly Light use

docs.title: Storage
docs.text:
• Keep backups off the Bambuddy server
  • Use cloud storage (Dropbox, Google Drive, etc.)
  • Keep multiple versions

docs.title: Testing
docs.text:
• Periodically test restoring
  • Verify backup integrity
  • Document your backup process

docs.title: Tips
docs.text:
Before Major Changes

Always backup before upgrading or making big configuration changes.

Off-Site Storage

Store at least one backup off-site (cloud or another location).

Regular Testing

Test your restore process periodically to ensure backups work.

Version in Filename

Include date and version in backup filenames for easy identification.

3MF Backup

For complete backup, also download your 3MF files separately.

docs.title: Camera Streaming
docs.text: Monitor your prints visually with live camera streaming directly from your Bambu Lab printer.

docs.title: Live Streaming
docs.text: Bambuddy provides MJPEG video streaming from your printer's built-in camera.

docs.title: Opening the Camera
docs.text:
1. Click the camera icon on any printer card
  2. A new window opens with the live feed
  3. The stream starts automatically

docs.title: Stream Controls
docs.text: Button Action Live Real-time MJPEG video stream Snapshot Single still image (lower bandwidth) Restart the stream Enter fullscreen mode

docs.title: Snapshot Mode
docs.text:
For lower bandwidth usage, use snapshot mode:

  • Captures a single frame on demand
  • Click refresh to get a new snapshot
  • Ideal for cellular connections or slow networks

docs.title: How Streaming Works
docs.text:
graph LR
    A[Printer Camera] -->|RTSP| B[ffmpeg]
    B -->|MJPEG| C[Bambuddy API]
    C -->|HTTP Stream| D[Browser]
  1. Printer exposes camera via RTSP (Real Time Streaming Protocol)
  2. ffmpeg converts RTSP to MJPEG (Motion JPEG)
  3. Bambuddy serves the MJPEG stream to your browser
  4. Browser displays frames in an <img> tag

docs.title: Requirements
docs.text: Requirement Details ffmpeg Must be installed on Bambuddy server Camera enabled Must be enabled in printer settings LAN Mode Camera access requires LAN Mode

docs.title: Installing ffmpeg
docs.text:
Ubuntu/Debian macOS Windows Docker 
sudo apt install ffmpeg

brew install ffmpeg

Download from ffmpeg.org and add to PATH.

ffmpeg is included in the Docker image.

docs.title: Camera Snapshots on Print Complete
docs.text:
Bambuddy can automatically capture a camera snapshot when prints complete:

  1. Go to Settings > General
  2. Enable Capture snapshot on print complete
  3. Snapshots are saved to the archive

This creates a visual record of your completed prints!

docs.title: Frame Rate
docs.text:
The default frame rate is 10 FPS. You can adjust this in the URL:

/api/v1/printers/{id}/camera/stream?fps=15
FPS Use Case 5 Low bandwidth 10 Default, balanced 15 Smoother video 30 Maximum quality

Higher FPS = More Bandwidth

Higher frame rates consume more network bandwidth and server resources.

docs.title: Stream Cleanup
docs.text:
Bambuddy properly cleans up camera streams:

  • Window close - Stream stops automatically
  • Tab hidden - Stream pauses to save resources
  • Page unload - ffmpeg process terminated
  • Refresh - Old stream stopped, new one started

  • ffmpeg processing

docs.title: Failure Analysis
docs.text: Understand why prints fail by analyzing patterns and correlating failures with environmental conditions, materials, and settings.

docs.title: Failure Dashboard
docs.text: The Failure Analysis widget on the Statistics page shows:

docs.title: Failure Rate
docs.text:
Overall success vs failure percentage:

Success: 89%  |  Failed: 8%  |  Stopped: 3%

docs.title: Failure Trend
docs.text:
Track if failure rate is:

  • Improving - Fewer failures over time
  • Stable - Consistent rate
  • Worsening - More failures recently

docs.title: Correlation Analysis
docs.text: Identify what's causing failures by analyzing correlations:

docs.title: By Material
docs.text:
Material Success Rate Failures PLA 95% 3 PETG 88% 8 ABS 75% 12 TPU 70% 6

Spot materials that need attention.

docs.title: By Printer
docs.text:
Printer Success Rate Failures Workshop X1C 92% 5 Office P1S 85% 10 Garage A1 78% 15

Identify problematic machines.

docs.title: By Time of Day
docs.text:
Time Success Rate Morning (6-12) 91% Afternoon (12-18) 89% Evening (18-24) 88% Night (0-6) 85%

Environmental factors may affect overnight prints.

docs.title: By Duration
docs.text:
Print Length Success Rate < 1 hour 95% 1-4 hours 91% 4-12 hours 87% > 12 hours 80%

Longer prints have more opportunities to fail.

docs.title: Environmental Factors
docs.text: If you have environmental data:

docs.title: Temperature Correlation
docs.text: Room Temp Success Rate 18-22°C 92% 22-26°C 88% > 26°C 82%

docs.title: Humidity Correlation
docs.text:
Humidity Success Rate < 40% 91% 40-60% 87% > 60% 78%

High humidity affects filament quality.

docs.title: Adhesion Failures
docs.text:
Symptoms:

  • Print detaches from bed
  • Warping corners
  • First layer issues

Correlations to check:

  • Bed temperature settings
  • Bed cleanliness (time since last clean)
  • Material type (ABS/PETG more prone)
  • Room temperature changes

docs.title: Layer Adhesion
docs.text:
Symptoms:

  • Delamination between layers
  • Weak parts
  • Cracks along layer lines

Correlations to check:

  • Nozzle temperature
  • Print speed
  • Cooling fan settings
  • Humidity (wet filament)

docs.title: Stringing/Oozing
docs.text:
Symptoms:

  • Strings between parts
  • Blobs on surface

Correlations to check:

  • Retraction settings
  • Temperature (too high)
  • Travel speed

docs.title: Spaghetti
docs.text:
Symptoms:

  • Tangled mess of filament
  • Print knocked off bed

Correlations to check:

  • Adhesion (root cause)
  • AI detection (was it enabled?)
  • Print complexity

docs.title: Step 1: Filter Failed Prints
docs.text:
1. Go to Archives
  2. Filter by Status: Failed
  3. Review the list

docs.title: Step 2: Look for Patterns
docs.text:
Check what failed prints have in common:

  • Same printer?
  • Same material?
  • Same time period?
  • Similar settings?

docs.title: Step 3: Compare with Success
docs.text:
Use Archive Comparison to compare a failed print with a successful one:

  1. Select a failed print and similar successful print
  2. Right-click > Compare
  3. Look for setting differences

docs.title: Step 4: Document Findings
docs.text:
Add notes to failed archives:

  • What you observed
  • Suspected cause
  • Changes made

docs.title: Failure Tags
docs.text:
Tag failed prints for easier analysis:

Tag Use For adhesion-fail Bed adhesion issues layer-fail Layer adhesion issues spaghetti Complete failures warping Warping issues stringing Quality issues

Filter by tags to see specific failure types.

docs.title: Photo Documentation
docs.text:
Add photos to failed prints:

  1. Open the failed archive
  2. Click Add Photo
  3. Upload images of the failure

Visual documentation helps:

  • Remember what went wrong
  • Share with others for help
  • Track if fixes work

docs.title: Quick Wins
docs.text:
1. Dry your filament - Wet filament causes many failures
  2. Clean your bed - Regular cleaning improves adhesion
  3. Level your bed - Run auto-leveling regularly
  4. Control temperature - Avoid drafts and temp swings

docs.title: Medium-term Fixes
docs.text:
1. Tune materials - Create profiles for each material
  2. Calibrate flow - Ensure correct extrusion
  3. Check hardware - Worn nozzles, loose belts

docs.title: Long-term Solutions
docs.text:
1. Track patterns - Use failure analysis regularly
  2. Document changes - Note what worked
  3. Preventive maintenance - Follow maintenance schedules

docs.title: Tips
docs.text:
Don't Delete Failures

Keep failed prints in your archive - they're valuable data for analysis.

Consistent Tagging

Use consistent tags for failures to enable filtering and pattern detection.

Photo Everything

Photos of failures are invaluable for diagnosis and tracking improvements.

Check the Obvious

Most failures are due to: wet filament, dirty bed, or temperature issues.

When fixing issues, change one thing at a time to know what worked.

docs.title: K-Profiles
docs.text: Manage pressure advance (K-factor) settings for optimal print quality across different filaments.

docs.title: What is Pressure Advance?
docs.text:
Pressure advance (K-factor) compensates for filament compression in the extruder:

  • Too low: Bulging corners, blobs at start
  • Too high: Gaps at corners, weak lines
  • Just right: Clean corners, consistent extrusion

Different filaments need different K values.

docs.title: K-Profile Storage
docs.text:
Bambuddy stores K-profiles per:

  • Printer - Each printer has its own values
  • Filament - Different K per material
  • Nozzle - Values vary by nozzle size

docs.title: From Printer
docs.text:
Pull current K-profiles from your printer:

  1. Go to K-Profiles page
  2. Select your printer
  3. Click Fetch from Printer
  4. K-values are downloaded

docs.title: What's Retrieved
docs.text: Data Description Material Filament type K-factor Pressure advance value Nozzle Nozzle diameter Notes Any stored notes

docs.title: To Printer
docs.text:
Send K-profiles to your printer:

  1. Go to K-Profiles page
  2. Select profiles to push
  3. Click Push to Printer
  4. Profiles are uploaded

Overwrites Existing

Pushing profiles overwrites the printer's current K values for that material.

docs.title: Modify Values
docs.text:
1. Click on a K-profile
  2. Edit the K-factor value
  3. Add optional notes
  4. Click Save

docs.title: Value Guidelines
docs.text:
Material Typical K Range PLA 0.02 - 0.06 PETG 0.06 - 0.12 ABS/ASA 0.04 - 0.08 TPU 0.20 - 0.50

These are starting points

Actual values depend on your specific printer, filament brand, and nozzle.

docs.text:

  2. Select material type
  3. Enter K-factor value
  4. Select nozzle size
  5. Add notes if desired
  6. Click Save

docs.text:
After running calibration:

  1. Note the optimal K value
  2. Add or update the profile
  3. Save for future use

docs.title: Running K-Factor Calibration
docs.text:
Bambu Lab printers include built-in calibration:

  1. Load the filament to calibrate
  2. From printer or Bambu Studio, run flow calibration
  3. Observe the test pattern
  4. Note the optimal K value

docs.text:

  • Marlin K-factor test patterns

  • Corner flow tests

Copy K-profiles to another printer:

  2. Click Copy to Printer

docs.text:
Calibrate Each Filament

Even same material from different brands may need different K values.

Note the Brand

Regular Updates

Start Conservative

When unsure, start with a lower K value and increase gradually.

Backup Before Changes

Export profiles before making major changes.

docs.title: Maintenance Tracker
docs.text: Schedule and track maintenance tasks to keep your printers running reliably.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
The maintenance tracker helps you:

  • Schedule recurring maintenance tasks
  • Track when maintenance was last performed
  • Get notified when maintenance is due
  • Log maintenance history

docs.title: Default Types
docs.text:
Bambuddy includes common maintenance tasks:

Type Default Interval Bed Cleaning Every 10 prints Lubrication Every 100 hours Belt Tension Every 200 hours Nozzle Check Every 50 prints HEPA Filter Every 500 hours Carbon Filter Every 500 hours

docs.title: Custom Types
docs.text:
Create your own maintenance tasks:

  1. Go to Settings > Maintenance
  2. Click Add Maintenance Type
  3. Enter name and description
  4. Set default interval
  5. Click Save

docs.title: Print Count
docs.text:
Schedule based on number of prints:

  • Example: Clean bed every 10 prints
  • Resets after maintenance is logged

docs.title: Print Hours
docs.text:
Schedule based on actual print time:

  • Example: Lubricate every 100 hours
  • Accumulated from print durations

docs.title: Calendar Days
docs.text:
Schedule based on calendar time:

  • Example: Check belts every 30 days
  • Counts calendar days regardless of usage

docs.title: Per-Printer Configuration
docs.text:
Each printer has its own maintenance schedule:

  1. Go to Maintenance page
  2. Select your printer
  3. Click Configure
  4. Enable/disable maintenance types
  5. Adjust intervals as needed
  6. Click Save

docs.title: Interval Customization
docs.text:
Override default intervals per printer:

Get notified when maintenance is due:

  1. Go to Settings > Notifications
  2. Enable Maintenance Due event
  3. Configure your notification provider

docs.title: Notification Timing
docs.text:
• Due Soon: When threshold reached
  • Overdue: When interval exceeded

Notification setup

docs.title: Maintenance Tips
docs.text:
Bed Cleaning

Clean with IPA between prints for best adhesion. Deep clean with dish soap weekly.

Lubrication

Use appropriate grease for linear rails. Don't over-lubricate.

Belt Tension

Belts should be firm but not overly tight. Use the "guitar string" test.

Nozzle Inspection

Check for wear, especially with abrasive filaments. Replace when worn.

Filters

HEPA and carbon filters lose effectiveness over time. Replace as recommended.

Document Everything

Add notes when logging maintenance to build a history of what works.

docs.title: Regular Schedule

  • Build maintenance into your routine

docs.text:

  • Reactive: Fix when broken
  • Preventive is better!

docs.title: WebSocket Architecture
docs.text:
Bambuddy uses WebSocket for real-time updates:

graph LR
    A[Printer] -->|MQTT| B[Bambuddy Backend]
    B -->|WebSocket| C[Browser]
    B -->|WebSocket| D[Browser 2]
    B -->|WebSocket| E[Mobile]

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
1. Printer sends status updates via MQTT over TLS
  2. Backend processes and stores the data
  3. WebSocket broadcasts updates to all connected clients
  4. Browser updates the UI instantly

docs.title: Queue Overview
docs.text:
The print queue lets you:

  • Queue prints from your archive
  • Order with drag-and-drop
  • Schedule specific start times
  • Automate with smart plug integration
  • Track queue progress

docs.title: From Archive
docs.text:
1. Go to Archives page
  2. Right-click an archive card
  3. Select Add to Queue
  4. Choose target printer
  5. Print is added to queue

docs.title: From Queue Page
docs.text:
1. Go to Queue page
  2. Click Add Print
  3. Browse and select an archive
  4. Choose target printer
  5. Optionally set schedule time

docs.title: Drag and Drop Ordering
docs.text:
Reorder prints in the queue:

  1. Hover over a queued print
  2. Grab the drag handle
  3. Drag to new position
  4. Release to reorder

Prints execute in order from top to bottom.

docs.title: Immediate Prints
docs.text:
Add to queue without a schedule - prints start when:

  • Printer is idle
  • Previous prints complete
  • No scheduled prints are pending

docs.title: Scheduled Prints
docs.text:
Set a specific start time:

  1. Click Schedule on queued print
  2. Choose date and time
  3. Print starts at scheduled time

docs.title: Schedule Priority
docs.text:
Scheduled prints take priority:

  1. Check for scheduled prints at scheduled time
  2. If none, check immediate queue
  3. Start next print

docs.title: Smart Plug Automation
docs.text: Combine with smart plugs for full automation:

docs.title: Auto Power On
docs.text:
When a queued print is ready:

  1. Bambuddy checks if printer is on
  2. If off and smart plug configured, powers on
  3. Waits for printer to boot
  4. Starts the print

docs.title: Auto Power Off
docs.text:
After print completes:

  1. Print completes
  2. Cooldown period (configurable)
  3. Check if more prints queued
  4. If no more prints, power off

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text:
1. Go to Settings > Smart Plugs
  2. Configure plug for printer
  3. Enable Auto Power On and Auto Power Off
  4. Set cooldown temperature and time

docs.title: Full-Text Search
docs.text: Bambuddy uses SQLite FTS5 (Full-Text Search) for lightning-fast search across all your archives.

docs.title: What's Searchable
docs.text: Field Example Print name "benchy" Filename "calibration_cube.3mf" Tags "functional" Notes "great layer adhesion" Designer "printables username" Filament type "PLA", "PETG", "ABS" Printer name "Workshop X1C"

docs.title: Search Syntax
docs.text: Syntax Description Example word Simple search benchy "phrase" Exact phrase "phone stand" word* Prefix match ben* matches "benchy" word1 word2 Both words phone stand word1 OR word2 Either word benchy OR boat -word Exclude word phone -case

docs.title: Performance
docs.text:
FTS5 provides near-instant search:

Archive Count Search Time 100 < 1ms 1,000 < 5ms 10,000 < 20ms 100,000 < 100ms

docs.title: Why FTS5?
docs.text:
• Tokenized index - Pre-processes text for fast lookup
  • Ranked results - Most relevant first
  • Incremental updates - Index updates automatically

docs.title: Keyboard Shortcuts
docs.text: Shortcut Action / Focus search box Esc Clear search / close Enter Execute search Down Navigate results

docs.title: Search Box Location
docs.text: The search box is prominently displayed on the Archives page header.

docs.title: Combining Search with Filters
docs.text:
Search works alongside other filters:

  1. Enter search term
  2. Apply additional filters (printer, date, status)
  3. Results show intersection

Example: Search "benchy" + filter by "Last 7 days" + filter by "Success"

docs.title: Search History
docs.text:
Recent searches are remembered:

  • Click the search box to see recent searches
  • Click any previous search to reuse it
  • Clear history in the search dropdown

docs.title: Index Management
docs.text: The search index is automatically maintained:

docs.title: Automatic Updates
docs.text:
• New archives are indexed immediately
  • Edits update the index
  • Deletions remove from index

docs.title: Manual Rebuild
docs.text:
If search results seem incorrect:

  1. Go to Settings > System
  2. Click Rebuild Search Index
  3. Wait for rebuild to complete

When to Rebuild

Index rebuild is rarely needed. Only use if search results are clearly wrong or after database restoration.

docs.title: API Search
docs.text:
Search via the REST API:

GET /api/v1/archives?search=benchy

Response includes matching archives with relevance ranking.

docs.title: API Parameters
docs.text: Parameter Description search Search query string limit Max results (default: 50) offset Pagination offset

docs.title: Search Tips
docs.text:
Use Specific Terms

More specific searches yield better results. "voron stealthburner" is better than just "voron".

Quote Phrases

Use quotes for exact phrases: "cable chain" won't match "cable management chain".

Exclude with Minus

Exclude unwanted results: case -phone finds cases that aren't phone cases.

Prefix for Partial Matches

Use asterisk for partial matching: bench* matches "benchy", "benchmark", "bench".

Check Filters

If search returns nothing, check if filters are limiting results.

docs.title: Smart Plugs
docs.text: Control your printers with Tasmota-based smart plugs for power monitoring, automation, and energy tracking.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Smart plug integration enables:

  • Power control - Turn printers on/off remotely
  • Energy monitoring - Track power consumption
  • Auto power-on - Start printer before scheduled prints
  • Auto power-off - Shut down after cooldown
  • Automation - Hands-free print scheduling

docs.title: Supported Plugs
docs.text:
Bambuddy supports Tasmota-flashed smart plugs:

Feature Required? Tasmota firmware Yes Power monitoring Recommended HTTP API access Yes

docs.title: Popular Options
docs.text:
• Sonoff S31 - Compact, power monitoring
  • Gosund SP111 - Affordable, power monitoring
  • Athom Plugs - Pre-flashed with Tasmota
  • Shelly Plug S - High quality, Tasmota compatible

Pre-flashed Plugs

Buy plugs pre-flashed with Tasmota to avoid the flashing process. Athom and some others sell them ready to use.

docs.title: Adding a Smart Plug
docs.text:
1. Go to Settings > Smart Plugs
  2. Click Add Smart Plug
  3. Enter configuration:
Field Description Name Friendly name IP Address Plug's network IP Printer Associated printer
  1. Click Save
  2. Click Test to verify connection

  2. Go to Information
  3. Note the IP Address

  2. Find connected devices

docs.text:

In TasmotaIn Router
  1. Go to plug web interface
  2. Configuration > Configure WiFi
  3. Enter static IP settings

Create a DHCP reservation for the plug's MAC address.

docs.text:
Toggle power from Bambuddy:

  1. Go to printer card
  2. Click the power icon

Or from Settings > Smart Plugs:

  • Click the power toggle for any plug

docs.title: Power Status
docs.text: Icon Status On Off Unreachable

docs.title: Auto Power On
docs.text:
Automatically turn on printer before prints:

  1. Enable Auto Power On for the plug
  2. When a queued print is ready:
  3. Bambuddy turns on the plug
  4. Waits for printer to boot
  5. Starts the print

docs.title: Auto Power Off
docs.text:
Automatically turn off after prints:

  1. Enable Auto Power Off for the plug
  2. Set Cooldown Temperature (e.g., 40°C)
  3. Set Cooldown Time (e.g., 5 minutes)
  4. After print completes:
  5. Wait for bed to cool below threshold
  6. Wait additional cooldown time
  7. Turn off the plug

docs.title: Safety Checks
docs.text:
Auto power-off includes safety checks:

  • Only triggers after successful prints
  • Waits for cooldown
  • Checks for queued prints
  • Verifies printer is idle

docs.title: Tasmota Commands
docs.text:
Bambuddy uses these Tasmota HTTP commands:

Action Command Turn On http://{ip}/cm?cmnd=Power%20On Turn Off http://{ip}/cm?cmnd=Power%20Off Status http://{ip}/cm?cmnd=Status%200 Energy http://{ip}/cm?cmnd=Status%208

docs.title: Testing Manually
docs.text:
# Turn on
curl "http://192.168.1.100/cm?cmnd=Power%20On"

# Get status
curl "http://192.168.1.100/cm?cmnd=Status%200"

docs.title: Don't Cut Power Mid-Print
docs.text:
Auto power-off is safe because:

  • Only triggers after print completion
  • Waits for cooldown
  • Checks printer state

Never manually power off during printing!

docs.title: Surge Protection
docs.text:
Consider adding surge protection:

  • Protects printer electronics
  • Protects smart plug
  • Especially important for unstable power

docs.title: Fire Safety
docs.text:
Smart plugs have current limits:

  • Most handle 10-15A
  • 3D printers typically draw 3-8A
  • Check your plug's rating

docs.title: Plug Not Responding
docs.text:
1. Check plug is powered
  2. Verify IP address is correct
  3. Ensure plug is on same network
  4. Check if Tasmota web interface loads
  5. Verify no firewall blocking

docs.title: Auto Power-Off Not Working
docs.text:
1. Check feature is enabled
  2. Verify cooldown settings
  3. Ensure print completed successfully
  4. Check for queued prints (won't power off if more queued)

docs.title: Power Data Incorrect
docs.text:
1. Not all plugs have power monitoring
  2. Calibrate in Tasmota: Configuration > Configure Other
  3. Check plug specifications

docs.title: Tips
docs.text:
Start Simple

Start with manual power control before enabling automation.

Test Cooldown

Monitor a few prints to find the right cooldown temperature for your printer.

Label Plugs

If you have multiple plugs, label them physically to match Bambuddy names.

Dedicated Circuit

If possible, put printers on a dedicated circuit to avoid tripping breakers.

Energy Baseline

Track energy for a week to establish your typical consumption baseline.

docs.title: Spoolman Integration
docs.text: Sync your AMS filament with Spoolman for complete spool tracking and inventory management.

docs.title: :material-spool: What is Spoolman?
docs.text:
Spoolman is a self-hosted filament inventory manager that:

  • Tracks spool quantities
  • Records filament usage
  • Manages multiple materials and vendors
  • Integrates with slicers

Bambuddy syncs your AMS slots with Spoolman for unified tracking.

docs.title: Requirements
docs.text:
• Spoolman instance running and accessible
  • Network access from Bambuddy to Spoolman

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text:
1. Go to Settings > Integrations
  2. Find Spoolman section
  3. Enter:
Field Description URL Spoolman server URL (e.g., http://192.168.1.50:7912) API Key If Spoolman requires authentication
  1. Click Test Connection
  2. Click Save

docs.title: AMS to Spoolman
docs.text:

docs.title: Enabling LAN Mode
docs.text:
Bambuddy connects to your printer via LAN Mode - a local connection that works without internet.

Why LAN Mode?

LAN Mode provides direct communication between Bambuddy and your printer over your local network. This means:

  • Works offline - No internet required
  • Fast response - Direct local connection
  • Your data stays local - No cloud dependency

docs.title: Step 1: Enable Developer Mode (if required)
docs.text:

  1. On your printer's touchscreen, go to Settings
  2. Navigate to General or About
  3. Look for Developer Mode and enable it

Note

Not all printers require this step. If you don't see Developer Mode, proceed to Step 2.

docs.title: Step 2: Enable LAN Mode
docs.text:
1. Go to Settings Network LAN Mode
  2. Toggle LAN Mode to ON
  3. Note down the Access Code displayed (8 characters)

Access Code Changes

The access code changes every time you toggle LAN Mode off and on. If you re-enable LAN Mode, you'll need to update the access code in Bambuddy.

docs.title: docker-compose.yml
docs.text:
The default docker-compose.yml works out of the box:

services:
  bambuddy:
    build: .
    ports:
      - "8000:8000"
    volumes:
      - ./bambuddy.db:/app/bambuddy.db
      - ./archive:/app/archive
      - ./logs:/app/logs
    restart: unless-stopped
    environment:
      - TZ=Europe/Berlin  # Your timezone

docs.text: Variable Default Description TZ UTC Your timezone (e.g., America/New_York) DEBUG false Enable debug logging LOG_LEVEL INFO Log level: DEBUG, INFO, WARNING, ERROR

docs.text:

ports:

docs.title: Reverse Proxy (Nginx)
docs.text:
To run Bambuddy behind a reverse proxy with HTTPS:

server {
    listen 443 ssl http2;
    server_name bambuddy.yourdomain.com;

    ssl_certificate /path/to/cert.pem;
    ssl_certificate_key /path/to/key.pem;

    location / {
        proxy_pass http://localhost:8000;
        proxy_http_version 1.1;
        proxy_set_header Upgrade $http_upgrade;
        proxy_set_header Connection "upgrade";
        proxy_set_header Host $host;
        proxy_set_header X-Real-IP $remote_addr;
        proxy_set_header X-Forwarded-For $proxy_add_x_forwarded_for;
        proxy_set_header X-Forwarded-Proto $scheme;

        # WebSocket support
        proxy_read_timeout 86400;
    }
}

WebSocket Support

Make sure your reverse proxy supports WebSocket connections - this is required for real-time printer updates.

docs.title: First Printer Setup
docs.text: This guide walks you through adding your first printer to Bambuddy.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
Before adding a printer, ensure:

  • Bambuddy is running (Installation or Docker)
  • Your printer is powered on and connected to your network
  • LAN Mode is enabled (see guide)
  • You have the IP address, serial number, and access code

docs.title: Step 1: Open the Add Printer Dialog
docs.text:
1. Open Bambuddy in your browser
  2. Go to the Printers page
  3. Click the Add Printer button

docs.title: Step 2: Enter Printer Details
docs.text:
Fill in the required information:

Field Description Example Name A friendly name for your printer Workshop X1C IP Address Your printer's local IP address 192.168.1.100 Access Code 8-character code from LAN Mode 12345678 Serial Number Your printer's serial number 01P00A000000001

Finding Serial Number

The serial number format varies by model:

  • X1 Series: Starts with 01S or 01P
  • P1 Series: Starts with 01P
  • A1 Series: Starts with 01A
  • H2 Series: Starts with 03W

docs.title: Step 3: Save and Connect
docs.text:
1. Click Save
  2. Bambuddy will attempt to connect to your printer
  3. Wait for the connection indicator to turn green

docs.title: Verifying Connection
docs.text: A successfully connected printer shows:

docs.title: Green Indicator
docs.text: Connection is active and healthy

docs.title: Live Temperatures
docs.text: Nozzle, bed, and chamber readings update in real-time

docs.title: HMS Status
docs.text: Health Management System shows "OK" (green)

docs.text: Element Description Connection indicator Green = connected, Red = disconnected Camera button Open live camera feed Settings button Edit printer settings Temperatures Live nozzle, bed, and chamber temps Progress bar Current print progress (if printing) Layer info Current layer / total layers Time remaining Estimated completion time Filament used Grams consumed this print AMS section Filament slots, humidity, and temperature HMS status Health status indicator

docs.title: Camera Setup
docs.text:
Bambuddy supports live camera streaming:

  1. Click the camera icon on the printer card
  2. A new window opens with the live feed
  3. Toggle between Live stream and Snapshot mode

Camera Requirements

  • Camera must be enabled in your printer settings
  • Requires ffmpeg installed on the Bambuddy server for MJPEG streaming
  • Works over LAN Mode connection

docs.title: Connection Issues?
docs.text: If your printer won't connect:

docs.title: Check These First
docs.text:
1. Is LAN Mode enabled? Re-check the setting on your printer
  2. Correct IP address? Verify in printer network settings
  3. Access code fresh? Codes change when LAN Mode is toggled
  4. Same network? Bambuddy server and printer must be on the same LAN
  5. Firewall rules? Ensure ports 8883 (MQTT) and 990 (FTPS) are open

docs.text: Indicator Meaning  Green Connected and communicating  Yellow Connecting or reconnecting  Red Disconnected or error

docs.title: Running as a Service
docs.text:
For production use, run Bambuddy as a system service that starts automatically.

systemd (Linux) launchd (macOS)

Create the service file:

sudo nano /etc/systemd/system/bambuddy.service

Add this content (adjust paths for your system):

[Unit]
Description=Bambuddy Print Archive
After=network.target

[Service]
Type=simple
User=YOUR_USERNAME
WorkingDirectory=/home/YOUR_USERNAME/bambuddy
Environment="PATH=/home/YOUR_USERNAME/bambuddy/venv/bin"
ExecStart=/home/YOUR_USERNAME/bambuddy/venv/bin/uvicorn backend.app.main:app --host 0.0.0.0 --port 8000
Restart=always
RestartSec=10

[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target

Enable and start:

sudo systemctl daemon-reload
sudo systemctl enable bambuddy
sudo systemctl start bambuddy

Check status:

sudo systemctl status bambuddy

View logs:

sudo journalctl -u bambuddy -f

Create the plist file:

nano ~/Library/LaunchAgents/com.bambuddy.plist

Add this content:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<!DOCTYPE plist PUBLIC "-//Apple//DTD PLIST 1.0//EN" "http://www.apple.com/DTDs/PropertyList-1.0.dtd">
<plist version="1.0">
<dict>
    <key>Label</key>
    <string>com.bambuddy</string>
    <key>ProgramArguments</key>
    <array>
        <string>/Users/YOUR_USERNAME/bambuddy/venv/bin/uvicorn</string>
        <string>backend.app.main:app</string>
        <string>--host</string>
        <string>0.0.0.0</string>
        <string>--port</string>
        <string>8000</string>
    </array>
    <key>WorkingDirectory</key>
    <string>/Users/YOUR_USERNAME/bambuddy</string>
    <key>RunAtLoad</key>
    <true/>
    <key>KeepAlive</key>
    <true/>
</dict>
</plist>

Load and start:

launchctl load ~/Library/LaunchAgents/com.bambuddy.plist

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text: Solutions for common issues with Bambuddy.

docs.title: Printer Won't Connect
docs.text:
Symptoms: Printer shows as disconnected, red indicator

Solutions:

  1. Verify LAN Mode is enabled
  2. Check printer: Settings > Network > LAN Mode

  3. Toggle off and on to get a fresh access code

  4. Check IP address

  5. Verify IP in printer network settings

  6. Ensure IP hasn't changed (use static IP or DHCP reservation)

  7. Verify access code

  8. Access code changes when LAN Mode is toggled

  9. Copy the code exactly (case-sensitive)

  10. Check network connectivity 

    ping YOUR_PRINTER_IP

  11. Verify ports are accessible

  12. MQTT: Port 8883
  13. FTPS: Port 990
telnet YOUR_PRINTER_IP 8883
  1. Check firewall rules
  2. Ensure Bambuddy server can reach printer
  3. Check both server and network firewalls

docs.title: Connection Drops Frequently
docs.text:
Symptoms: Printer connects but disconnects intermittently

Solutions:

  1. Check WiFi signal strength
  2. View signal strength on printer card

  3. Move printer closer to router if weak

  4. Network congestion

  5. Too many devices on network

  6. Try a dedicated network/VLAN

  7. Router issues

  8. Restart router
  9. Check for firmware updates

  10. Disable "smart" features that may interfere

  11. Check Bambuddy logs 

    tail -f logs/bambuddy.log

docs.title: Wrong Printer Status
docs.text:
Symptoms: Status shows idle when printing, or vice versa

Solutions:

  1. Wait for sync
  2. Status updates every few seconds

  3. Refresh the page

  4. Check MQTT debug

  5. Enable MQTT debug logging

  6. Verify messages are being received

  7. Restart connection

  8. Delete printer from Bambuddy
  9. Re-add with correct details

docs.title: Prints Not Being Archived
docs.text:
Symptoms: Prints complete but don't appear in archives

Solutions:

  1. Check printer connection
  2. Must be connected during and after print

  3. Verify green connection indicator

  4. Check FTP access

  5. Port 990 must be accessible

  6. Try downloading a file manually

  7. Check disk space

  8. Ensure enough space for 3MF files

  9. Clear old files if needed

  10. Check logs for errors 

    grep -i "archive\|error" logs/bambuddy.log

docs.title: Duplicate Archives
docs.text:
Symptoms: Same print appears multiple times

Solutions:

  1. Enable duplicate detection
  2. Go to Settings > General

  3. Enable duplicate detection

  4. Clean up duplicates

  5. Filter archives by name
  6. Delete unwanted duplicates

docs.title: Missing Thumbnails
docs.text:
Symptoms: Archive cards show placeholder instead of thumbnail

Solutions:

  1. Check 3MF file
  2. Some files don't include thumbnails

  3. Re-slice with thumbnail enabled

  4. Regenerate thumbnails

  5. Bambuddy can regenerate from 3MF
  6. Check Settings > Maintenance

docs.title: Camera Won't Stream
docs.text:
Symptoms: Camera page shows error or black screen

Solutions:

  1. Check ffmpeg installation 
    ffmpeg -version

Install if missing: 

# Ubuntu/Debian
sudo apt install ffmpeg

# macOS
brew install ffmpeg

  1. Verify camera is enabled
  2. Check printer settings

  3. Camera must be enabled in LAN Mode settings

  4. Check connection

  5. Camera requires active printer connection

  6. Verify printer shows as connected

  7. Try snapshot mode

  8. Click "Snapshot" instead of "Live"
  9. May work when streaming doesn't

docs.title: Stream Freezes
docs.text:
Symptoms: Video starts but freezes

Solutions:

  1. Network bandwidth
  2. Lower FPS setting

  3. Check network congestion

  4. Check ffmpeg processes 

    ps aux | grep ffmpeg

Kill orphaned processes: 

killall ffmpeg

  1. Refresh the stream
  2. Click refresh button
  3. Close and reopen camera page

docs.title: Notifications Not Sending
docs.text:
Symptoms: No notifications received

Solutions:

  1. Test the provider
  2. Go to Settings > Notifications
  3. Click "Send Test"

  4. Check for errors

  5. Verify configuration

  6. Double-check API keys/tokens

  7. Verify phone numbers include country code

  8. Check quiet hours

  9. Notifications suppressed during quiet hours

  10. Verify current time vs quiet hours setting

  11. Check event triggers

  12. Ensure desired events are enabled
  13. Check printer filter settings

docs.title: Notification Variables Empty
docs.text:
Symptoms: Messages show "Unknown" or blank for variables

Solutions:

  1. Update to latest version

  2. Variable handling improved in recent versions

  3. Check print data

  4. Some variables require specific print data
  5. May show "Unknown" for incomplete prints

docs.title: Database Errors
docs.text:
Symptoms: 500 errors, data not saving

Solutions:

  1. Check disk space 

    df -h

  2. Verify database integrity 

    sqlite3 bambuddy.db "PRAGMA integrity_check;"

  3. Restore from backup

  4. If corrupted, restore from backup
  5. See Backup & Restore guide

docs.title: Search Not Working
docs.text:
Symptoms: Search returns no results or wrong results

Solutions:

  1. Rebuild FTS index
  2. Go to Settings > System Info

  3. Click "Rebuild Search Index"

  4. Check search syntax

  5. Use quotes for exact phrases
  6. Check for typos

docs.title: Plug Not Responding
docs.text:
Symptoms: Can't control smart plug

Solutions:

  1. Verify IP address
  2. Check plug still has same IP

  3. Use static IP or DHCP reservation

  4. Test Tasmota interface

  5. Open http://PLUG_IP in browser

  6. Verify Tasmota web interface loads

  7. Check network access 

    curl "http://PLUG_IP/cm?cmnd=Status%200"

docs.title: Auto Power-Off Not Working
docs.text:
Symptoms: Printer doesn't turn off after print

Solutions:

  1. Check feature is enabled

  2. Settings > Smart Plugs > Auto Power Off

  3. Verify cooldown settings

  4. Check temperature threshold

  5. Check cooldown time

  6. Check for queued prints

  7. Won't power off if more prints queued

docs.title: Bambuddy Won't Start
docs.text:
Solutions:

  1. Check Python version 

    python3 --version  # Need 3.10+

  2. Check dependencies 

    pip install -r requirements.txt

  3. Check port availability 

    lsof -i :8000

  4. Check logs 

    cat logs/bambuddy.log

docs.title: Slow Performance
docs.text:
Solutions:

  1. Check system resources 

    htop

  2. Vacuum database

  3. Settings > System Info > Vacuum Database

  4. Clear old logs

  5. Logs rotate automatically

  6. Delete very old log files if needed

  7. Check for runaway processes 

    ps aux | grep -E "ffmpeg|python"
